title: How do you define Trolling?

replies.body: Engaging in negative behavior with the sole intention of bothering others.

> [{quoted}](name=Colonel J,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=AE9REci2,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2018-11-30T03:47:48.075+0000)
>
> Engaging in negative behavior with the sole intention of bothering others.

I just reported another player who refused to stop trolling.

Twice they ran into my lane with enemy with LOW HP did not commit to the fight.

They were asked to stop wouldn't stop, came back and started farming, taking XP and CS.

Pretty much threw the entire match intentionally upsetting me and causing 3 other plalyers as well as myself to lose match.

**I hope riot lets this player know this type of griefing / trolling, and intentionally upsetting people trying to bait arguments in chat isn't wanted <3.**

Characterisitcs of troll for me:
1) moves and communication opposite to each other
2) clear statement of intended trolling and followed up actions
3) frequent stupid actions/moves regardless intentional or not
4) descreasing own effectiveness for ineffective actions/moves (e.g flaming, whining, giving advices with low possibility of positive change)

I mean, at the end of the day we are by definition arguing semantics hereâ€¦ but following your logic a stupid player would be a troll.
I'd understand (even though I disagree) if you would **consider** somebody a troll if in doubt, therefore including stupid players as a false positive of sorts. But including stupid players in the very definition of the word seems odd to me.

Well, I was very specific in the use of ignorant as it has a different definition than stupid. 

**Ignorant**: 
lacking knowledge, information, or awareness about a particular thing

discourteous or rude

angry or quick-tempered.

**stupid**:
having or showing a great lack of intelligence or common sense


I say ignorant because we all are at different levels and are all learning as we go, aiming to win as best we can (except those who troll to lose the game/get others in trouble). This game isn't purely based around common sense, but also knowing the strengths of your character and the strengths of your opponents character better than your opponent and applying a tactical counter measure to their efforts. And I find that many players cannot take any form of critique, stern of polite, without being discourteous or angry at the attempt. They take it as a personal attack against them rather than an attempt to help them win the game where their current efforts are doing the opposite.

{{sticker:sona-playing}}

Just so we don't run into further misunderstandings: I wasn't replying to you.
The point you make, I admit, is a bit more nuanced than the one I was replying to. If I understand what you are saying correctly, you are not implying ignorant players to be trolls, but those who refuse to take advice and therefore effectively intentionally remain ignorant.

The tricky thing about advice, though: You have no "authority", for the lack of a better word. How do I know whether taking your advice is a good idea? How do **you** know that your advice wasn't actually considered? How do you know that the person failing to execute your advice didn't have some sort of thought process that made their action the most reasonable? Mind you, in this case I'm talking only about the first example you've given:

>When you ask the support to hang back by the turret while you back, or at least stand behind minions, so they don't get pulled by Thresh or Blitzcrank and die to the ADC, but it all happens just like that anyways. 

Your other examples, where people become defensive or even aggressive about being critiqued are something else entirely. In those cases I would still not use the word "troll". But that's the point where it's really just semantics. Whatever you want to call them, those people are horrible to play with and can really be more frustrating than anything else.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=AE9REci2,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2018-11-30T18:19:04.447+0000)
>
> The tricky thing about advice, though: You have no "authority", for the lack of a better word. How do I know whether taking your advice is a good idea?

At that point an astute player has to evaluate their current conditions vs the conditions suggested. They can A) continue to do what they are doing even though it continues to prove to lead to a bad ending or B) Do something other than they are doing. 

Option A) **proves** to lead to a bad ending, option B) gives you a chance at a different ending. 
But this is precisely where the ego begins to overshadow judgement. The player becomes emotional after dieing 3 times doing it exactly their way, and all they know to do is double and triple-down on what they are doing thats making them die. I NEED HELP I CANT FIGHT THEM ALONE. Now, a few of us will let them know "it might be wise to stop trying to fight them then and instead focus on farming" to which they say they are muting you for toxicity and begin to ping for 5 minutes straight and instead of focusing on farming continue to fight them to theirs and the teams detriment. Whether or not the advice is good or bad or the player "has the right to give advice" is immaterial in the face of the ulterior option, the player doing the same over and over and expecting a different result. I think they call that insanity. 

{{sticker:sona-playing}}

> [{quoted}](name=Ä± Sona Ä±,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=AE9REci2,comment-id=00010000000000000000,timestamp=2018-11-30T20:06:17.508+0000)
>
> Option A) proves to lead to a bad ending

Not quite. **You** have seen **evidence** that suggests it leads to a bad ending. The player in question could have lots of other games suggesting their approach works out.

Let's use a specific example: When I mained Sivir I at some point was really good at baiting Blitz hooks in order to regenerate mana by blocking it with my spell shield. But regardless of your training, occasionally things can go wrong. And as probability dictates that also means that there were entire games, however rare, where this went wrong constantly.

In this instance you might see evidence that my tactic fails, even though I know that if I get my act together I can make it work.

Edit: This all basically goes in the same direction as outcome bias. Just because a decision has created a bad outcome does not necessarily make it a bad decision.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=AE9REci2,comment-id=000100000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-11-30T21:07:18.961+0000)
>
> Edit: This all basically goes in the same direction as outcome bias. Just because a decision has created a bad outcome does not necessarily make it a bad decision.

I'm not talking about those _**rare character specific**_ strategy scenarios that don't quite go right but are intended for good purpose. In fact I listed some scenarios very specifically, like the mid laner who keeps hyper pushing over and over and dies over and over because they are being camped for it, or the top laner who keeps trying to 1 v 1 but 5 deaths later has not succeeded. 

You may be misinterpreting things and for that I forgive you. But lets be clear, I only suggested things That Lead To A Bad Ending. like a Miss Fortune without flash but farming right under the enemy turret  with no wards no ally jungle to counter gank and no means of escape should a gank happen (with the assumption that the enemy junglers last location is not known) is indeed showing **_strong evidence_** of a bad ending, primarily to seasoned players. This isn't MY OPINION of the end result, this is the most likely end result, getting ganked and dieing for it by being in a scenario that perfectly sets up for it, with the assumption you are at a tier level where such things are expected to happen as predicated by the average skill level. As a game of chess we might not always know the perfectly best move but those who really play at least learn a series of Optimal choices in the current scenario. 

Baiting out the grab to regen mana and failing is not the same as trying to 1 v 1 someone you are unable to 1 v 1 at the time over and over despite the outcome being the same after 5 deaths. Your strategy has a least a reasonably positive outcome and a measured chance of success. While shutdown gold from the person you fed 5 deaths to would be a minimum positive outcome, the experience of the scenario is already weighing against the likeliness of it ever happening in a 1 v 1 scenario unless the enemy totally messes up, which after 5 times succeeding in defeating you seems to suggest the enemy has a better grasp on the scenario. 

Feeding and trying to prove how good you are =/= a tactic, nor a viable means to win. Being unable to listen to rational communication advice from teammates =/= a viable tactic to winning.

{{sticker:sona-playing}}

I was merely trying to make clear that not everything that ends badly, and not even everything that in your experience ends badly most of the time, has to necessarily be a bad decision.
But I guess with those specific examples your point is more than fair. Thanks for elaborating.

I define a troll as someone who is intentionally being a non-productive or counter-productive member of the team.

So, behaviors including, but not limited to:

-Intentional feeding.
-AFKing or other forms of non-participation
-Intentionally blocking or altering allies' movement to their detriment (such as with Anivia's wall or Tahm Kench's W, Kalista's Black Spear, or just body blocking)
-Intentionally disrupting an ally's ability to do their job (such as following the jungler around and attempting to last hit all the creeps)
-Supplying the opposing team with information advantageous to them, such as the position of member(s) of your team, the position of your team's wards, or where your team is headed.
If you act like you don't want to win the game and intentionally lose the game for your team , you are trolling.

In my opinion a troll is someone who is intentionally trying to ruin the game for other people.  Although I get where you're going coming from with refusing reasonable communication, that too me is more being toxic than trolling.  They are still (At least in your definition) trying to play the game properly, they just aren't being sportsmanlike players.

**(NOTE, The following is my opinion in normal's.  I only play ranked for my promo's, ,aside from an occasional game, so my opinion doesn't apply to that game mode)**
I also don't include people who play off-meta in my definition of trolling.  There's a big difference between someone who picks Darius support because he wanted top and got auto-filled, and someone who's playing support, but is just playing a character that normally isn't a support.  As many of my friends will tell you, I love playing some really off-meta builds (All hail Darkk-Mane).  Normally I'll only do this in 5 man's, since I've gotten tired of every loss being blamed on me regardless of how well I'm actually doing that game, but I still enjoy doing it.
I think players with a vision score of 10 or less after 30 minutes are trolling. WARDS ARE FREE, USE THEM!

It's self explanatory and there's no need to think super deep about it. Just by looking at a situation I'm pretty sure everyone can instantly judge whether or not someone is trolling. 

If someone isn't trying to win the game, and actually wants to lose then yes, it's trolling.

If {{champion:11}} Farms in the jungle and never ganks, but still at 30 minutes flanks a team fight with his 6 items from the 400 CS he has, that is not trolling. 

If {{champion:11}} Farms in the jungle and never ganks, and at 30 minutes ignores a fight he could obviously help in, then that's trolling.
i define it as purposefully doing things that bother people or throw matches with negative intent being the driving force
I generally save the chat box for all chat. Emotes are enough for my team.

Typically people who outright try to make the game miserable and then report anyone who dares lash out at them for being a blatant ass are at the top of my list. They know if they don't say anything in chat what so ever the odds of getting noticed go down massively.

When the jungle jungles for 20 minutes straight without ever ganking, even if they are on your side of the map and the enemy is under your tower. Better yet, I think its pretty troll when the support roams into other lanes "to gank" even if the first 3 tries were unsuccessful and they are down 2 levels from the enemy support.
Excessive chatting.
Acting with the explicit intent of making the game less enjoyable or more difficult for your allies.

Hmm I always thought that trolling had only something to do with people making jokes/ having fun at the expense of others.

Trolling to me is the player who knows how to only play one role and one character but joins ranked consistently,  reducing the chances of everyone around them in climbing with their lacking knowledge of fundamentals and basics.
The worst trolls are always ezreals who do the blue build but never use his autoattacks and only use abilities.  Oh wait, they are actually trying
Trolling to me means: playing the game with the goal to make the game worse for others. Any other annoying thing could still be reportable but my definition of trolling stops there.

To me, trolling is not flaming or inting. A troll is simply someone whos goal does not allign with the goal the game had in mind. This includes things as objective goals (Destroy Nexus and Turrets, not camp in the jungle) and champion goals (Varus wants attackspeed and ad/on-hit not AP)

However, destroying the Nexus should still be a goal, it's just not their first.
